text.p: Taiwan's stock exchange said on Thursday 163 executives and major shareholders in 89 listed firms had taken T$21.6 million in "inappropriate" profits from the first half of 1995.

Under exchange rules, if executives or shareholders buy back their own firms' shares within six months of selling them, or vice versa, they are considered to be taking inappropriate profits and are subject to discipline, he said.
The exchange said unless the money was returned the profit-takers could face disciplinary action.

"We hold such an inspection every half year," an exchange official said by telephone. "This is not as serious as insider trading, but they still should return these inappropriate profits to their companies."
The violators included directors, supervisors, managers and big shareholders with more than 10 percent of a listed firm's shares, he said.
